title: Can I keep my vehicle, valued at approximately 15,000 with no lien holder, if I file bankruptcy in California?
question: We have no equity in anything except our personal vehicle & our work truck. Each have a value of about 15,000 and nothing owed on them. We owe more on our home than what it's worth, we have a travel trailer with a lien slightly less that what is owed & that is all we have, except alot of debt, credit cards and taxes. We just want to keep our vehicles & will give up our home.
question_tags: Debt collection for businesses,Chapter 13 bankruptcy for businesses,Liquidating business assets,Bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy liquidation,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Business
answers:
I understand the vehicles are valued at 30,000 (and there are no liens) and those are your only assets. Make sure the vehicles are really worth that much. They might be worth less. Also when the trustee looks at the value of your vehicles he subtracts what the projected costs of sale would be. This could be 15 - 20%. Let's assume the trustee uses a 15% cost of sale figure.

30,000 - 15% = 25,500
25,500 - 3300 car exemption = 22,200
The wildcard exemption is 22,075.

So it looks like the vehicles will be exempt. Wost case scenario you might have to pay a small amount to the trustee to keep the vehicles but trustees don't usually bother with such small amounts







m

People often ask if they can keep homes, second homes, cars, boats, tax refunds, etc., when they are contemplating Bankruptcy. I always tell them they can keep what they want of they can pay for it, or if the equity or value is protected by an exemption in their State!

There are two types of Bankruptcy for most individuals. Chapter 7 (liquidation) and Chapter 13 (payments are made to a Chapter 13 Trustee to be distributed pursuant to a Plan you and your attorney draft). To determine of you get to keep the property you have to know two things…

1) What is the equity in the property? (I.e., what is it worth minus what you owe on it).
2) Will the exemption laws that are applied to the property protect the equity?

Bankruptcy is much more concerned with equity than it is with debt. If you have no equity in a rental home the Trustee in a 7 or 13 does not have an interest in the property and you may keep it.

If you owe more on the vacation home than it is worth you may be able to use Bankruptcy to reduce the amount of the debt, and again, keep it.

When you have equity in something that is not protected by an exemption then that is an issue that a lawyer must evaluate. See an attorney right away before you act.

Good Luck!

The exemption for equity in a car is $3,300 and in addition you would have $20,725 in wild card exemption that could be applied to the vehicles. Even with these exemptions it still appears that depending on the value of your vehicles you might have some unprotected assets. In which case you could file a chapter 13 bankruptcy and protect the vehicles, but you would end up with a chapter 13 repayment plan.
